templateAssets.content:
For transfer applicants, the following courses and substitutions can be used as major prep admission. While transfer students are required to complete four major preparation courses for admission by spring before transfer, transfer students are strongly encouraged to complete all major preparation requirements by spring before to transfer. 

PA 10: Social Problems and Social Change>no equivalency, students will take this at UCLA

PA 20: Power, Politics, and Policy Change in U.S> Students should look for the equivalency of UCLA's POLSCI 40 ( Introduction to American Politics)

PA 30: Comparative Analysis of Wealth, Policy, and Power> Students should look for the equivalent of UCLA's POLSCI 50. (Introduction to Comparative Politics)

PA 40: Microeconomics for Public Affairs> Students should look for the equivalent of UCLA's Econ 1 or Econ 11 (Microeconomics)

PA 50: Foundations and Debates in Public Thought>Students should look for the equivalent of UCLA’s POLISCI 10 (Introduction to Political Theory)

PA 60: Using Data to Learn about Society: An Introduction to Empirical Research and Statistics> Students should look for the equivalent of Statistics 10 (Introduction to Statistical Reasoning)

PA 70: Information, Evidence, and Persuasion> no equivalency, students will take this at UCLA

PA 80: How Social Environments Shape Human Development. Students should look for a course focused on lifespan human development (preferred) or child and adolescent development

courses.courseTitle: Using Data to Learn about Society: Introduction to Empirical Research and Statistics

templateAssets.content:
The Public Affairs major offers an in-depth and engaged educational experience with a clear public service ethos. Drawing from UCLA Luskin's expansive resources in Public Policy, Social Welfare, and Urban Planning, the major combines critical thinking, social science methodology, and experiential learning, connecting the dots between theory and action. During the senior year, students complete a three-quarter experiential learning program that combines a year-long internship in a community or government organization with a seminar series in which students develop a capstone project.


Listed below are the lower division preparation courses for the major.


To be considered for this major, you must complete a MINIMUM OF FOUR major preparation courses prior to transfer:

  • Complete One course in Microeconomics and One course in Introduction to Statistical Reasoning by the end of the fall prior to transfer; and
  • Complete at least Two courses from the following by the spring before transfer
  • Introduction to American Politics
  • Comparative Politics
  • Introduction to Political Theory


Students must take all major prep courses for a letter grade and receive a B grade or better in these courses to be competitive.

Additional major prep is STRONGLY RECOMMENDED.


To be considered for admission, applicants to the Public Affairs pre-major must have a minimum cumulative 3.2 GPA in all transferable coursework at the end of the fall. Students must attain junior level standing (at least 60 semester/90 quarter transferable units) by the end of spring prior to transfer. You must be admitted directly as a Public Affairs premajor. You will not be able to change into this major after admission to UCLA. California Community College students are strongly encouraged to complete IGETC; all other transfer students are encouraged to make progress toward completion of the Luskin School's general education requirements.


For more information regarding this major and UCLA's transfer selection process, visit https://luskin.ucla.edu/undergrad and https://admission.ucla.edu.


PLEASE NOTE: the community college courses listed below have been approved to satisfy preparation for this major at UCLA, but they may not be exact equivalents of the UCLA courses listed.
